posts.name: Nihat
posts.cooked:
Hello,

So we are currently starting as a new team to FRC . The need of swervedrive was seem to be essential to build a really nice robot. The thing is, they get really overwhelming when I dont really know what to loo for or not. To clarify, we want something fast and it should have good agility but dont know where to start.

I have checked the market on swerve modules. There are Andymark, REV, WestCoast etc.

Can you guys give advice to buy swerve modules and explain the terms like pinions and their size, gear ratio, First stage gear and second stage gear etc.

posts.name: Bryce Hanson
posts.cooked:
nwat:

The need of swervedrive was seem to be essential to build a really nice robot

I’m going to push back on this. While you will definitely see a lot of teams on swerve, these are teams that have the resources to execute swerve in the offseason. It’s expensive and can be very time-consuming to get everything working. You’d need to have your modules ordered and assembled very soon to begin testing, otherwise you’re probably better off using the KOP ( or an upgraded version ) and focusing on your mechanism designs to make sure you can score points and positively contribute to match outcomes.

That all being said, SwerveDriveSpecialties is the most common module, probably followed by WCP or REV. ThriftyBot has recently redesigned theirs and so it’s less tested (though the teams that have run them really like them). I probably wouldn’t venture outside of those 4.

posts.name: Nihat
posts.cooked: We have around 2k$ to 4k$ to spend for swerve modules, I think that’d be enough for it, thank you for your suggestions

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
If you are risk-averse as I am, then you need 6 modules. SDS and CTRE equipment will set you back closer to $5000, I think.

This catalog page has the speeds of various gear ratios for MK4 and Kraken (and others).

link_counts.title: MK4 Swerve Module – Swerve Drive Specialties

posts.name: Nihat
posts.cooked: Thank you I will check it out
Currently the most affordable swerve module is the REV robotics MAXswerve, although definitely look at all of your options, Thrifty swerve from The Thrifty Bot is affordable and looks good as well.

Although I definitely second the idea of investing more in other areas, as you can 100% be a successful team without swerve. Swerve is pretty easy mechanically, as it is just something you buy and slap 4 into a square, the trouble with it is programming, and how expensive and time consuming it is. Mechanisms can definitely get you further if you spend more time and effort on them.

In the current state of FRC , swerve is essential to be a competitive robot. I don’t consider my team exactly privileged with resources (we have two full time mentors neither of which work in a robotics/engineering related field). The past season we tried swerve and used REV Maxswerve. It was one of the only ones in stock when we were looking and worked pretty well.

Here is what we did to succeed in using swerve as a small team.

Used and modified the MaxSwerve library (insert whichever one you choose) so software wouldn’t become an issue

Bought COTS parts to make sure everything was reliable, easily replaceable, and didn’t rely on student’s engineering

Assembled the drivetrain in week one of build season (one guy did that alone so team size shouldn’t be an issue)

Wired and tested code in week two (I did that by myself as well so again team size shouldn’t be an issue)

Remember that what my team did may not work for everyone. I’m not endorsing REV MaxSwerve either, it’s just what was available. My team is in the process of deciding which modules to use next season.

If you still aren’t sure whether to chose swerve or tank, just remember to NEVER pick mecanum.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
First of all, do your own research (obviously), this isn’t to say ignore advice on CD , just that it’s good to form your own opinions based on the raw data.

Secondly, if this is your first year as a team you are going to learn so much it’s bonkers. If you have folks on your team that have done FRC before, swerve could be viable. Or if you have mentors who are deep into engineering and programming it could be viable. If you are paired with another FRC team (which I highly recommend) it could be viable.

Just make sure to not dive into this with no knowledge of FRC . Pair with another team.

Some teams are competitive their rookie year. It’s 100% possible to do, just super difficult. You are goin to spend a lot of time learning and you should put your all in without putting all your hopes and dreams on it. Think of “hope for the best, expect the worst”.

If you choose to do swerve (which isn’t a bad choice just be ready for some work!), then please please please assemble and test it as much as you can before kickoff weekend. If it’s not working by then assess and decide. Don’t spend your season on a drive train.

As for electronics I highly recommend CTRE (if you have the money for it) and using the swerve generator and libraries. It basically guarantees you will have good code. It’s expensive but makes you very competitive.

KEEP IN MIND:

Wiring is KEY to a successful robot. Please consider how you do you wiring. If you need help, feel free to reach out to 2491, we are working on seriously improving our wiring this year.

Big tips:

current limit your drive trains and any motors drawing a lot of amps from your battery. You do NOT want to pop your main breaker on field.

Make liberal use of ferrules

use the right size mounting screws for your motors (don’t jam them in and don’t have screws too long)

Read the docs!!

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
I’m worried for you if you are asking what “gear ratio” means and you are wanting to jump straight into swerve.  With high-quality modules readily available and many options for swerve chassis starter code also available,  swerve has become reachable for rookie teams.  However, that doesn’t mean it’s reachable for ALL rookie teams.  If you’ve got some skilled mentor help in mechanical and programming disciplines (not necessarily with FRC experience), fall is a great time to try to get a swerve chassis up and running.  However, if your team is essentially students trying to figure everything out, the Kitbot and differential drive is the best option for year 1.

With that being said, the questions you have about gearing are just as relevant for the Kitbot or any differential drive chassis as they are for swerve modules.  Some learning resources include:

Team 610’s design tutorials (gear and gearbox sections)

Spectrum’s Mechanical Advantage slides and video

Spectrum’s Beginner Swerve slides and video

For swerve starter code, some options include:

CTRE Swerve Project Generator (good luck finding Kraken motors)

Rev MAXSwerve template

YAGSL

AdvantageKit :: Swerve Drive Project

link_counts.title: Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
A few other comments to answer questions.

A pinion is another name for the small gear in a set.  In FRC , we almost always use gears to reduce motor speed and increase torque, so the pinion is the gear that is attached to the motor shaft.  Pinions often have bores designed to fit a specific motor shaft like the round 8mm keyed shaft of a NEO or the unique splined shaft of a Kraken.

Gear ratio is the ratio of teeth in the driven gear compared to the driving gear.  For example, if the pinion on a motor shaft has 12 teeth and the gear that it meshes with and drives has 48 teeth, the gear ratio is 48:12, simplifying to 4:1.  The driven gear will spin 4 times more slowly than the driving gear and it will apply 4 times more torque to its shaft compared to the torque of the motor shaft.

For a swerve module, three pairs of gears (stages) are usually compounded together to get a desired overall gear reduction from the motor to the wheel and to transfer the torque from the motor shaft on one plane to the wheel axle on a different plane.  Typical geartrain compounding in a swerve module is explained very well in the Beginner Swerve video linked above.  The overall gear ratio you see in swerve manufacturer product pages (Low/Medium/High, L1/L2/L3, etc.)  is the final result of this compounding.  Using an SDS MK4i as an example,

The L3 gear ratio of 6.12:1 is computed as 50/14 * 16/28 * 45/15 = 6.12.  For every 6.12 rotations of the motor shaft, the wheel rotates 1 time.  This is faster than the L1 geartrain, for example, which requires the motor shaft to rotate 8.14 times for the same 1 rotation of the wheel.

Selecting a gear ratio for the drive side of swerve is not as simple as “faster is better”.  Geartrains with higher output gear ratio get more torque as a tradeoff for less speed.  More torque results in greater acceleration.  An L1-geared robot would accelerate quicker, but have lower top-end speed compared to an L3-geared robot.  If a game required a lot of short moves with changes of direction, L1 could be practically faster than L3, especially for a heavy robot.  If the game required a lot of full-field runs, L3 is likely to be practically faster as the robot would have the time to accelerate to top-end speed and take advantage when that is higher.  Lower gear ratios will also draw more current from the battery, which will drop the available voltage and reduce real-life speed compared to calculations using a 12V standard.  There are simulators that can help you understand how your robot might perform in real-life with different drive gear ratios.

For example, reca.lc shows that a SDS MK4i L3 ratio on a 120 lb robot using NEOs as drive motors might make a 40 ft run at full throttle in 3.00 sec .  Bus voltage gets pulled down to about 8.3 V if drive motor current limits are set to 60A, which is getting close to brownout zone.  If you had questionable batteries or wiring, it might be even closer to brownout.  For the same robot with L1 gearing, the 40 ft would take 3.64 sec .  The voltage still gets pulled down to 8.3, but for a shorter time.

If you were trying to make a 5 ft run at max throttle, L3 would do it in 0.76 sec , while L1 would only take 0.68 sec .

Regardless of drive gear ratio, to make a faster and more agile robot, make a lighter robot with a lower center of gravity.

If I were buying swerve modules for a rookie team to play an unknown game, I’d select a middle gear ratio to balance acceleration and speed, while being slightly less demanding of the battery than lower (faster) ratios. It’s not hard to change the ratio later by replacing some of the gears if you find a clear reason to change.
